utterances: As an experiment for NPR about Occupy Wall Street, Gourley sorted through 40,000 blogs and articles written since it began and grouped similar ideas together.
You can't read all this as a human or even necessarily get what's going on, so you start to apply algorithms to help kind of cluster, sort, put topics around them and ultimately visualize.
What Gourley's algorithms help visualize is how ideas that germinated at the initial Occupy Wall Street rallies in New York spread to other groups and parts of the country.
Gourley opens up a computer screen filled with dots grouped into color clusters that look like different solar systems with thin lines that connect them.
One cluster represents politicians talking about taxing the wealthy.
It's far away from the protesters.
When the participants talk about Occupy Wall Street, they're not really talking in Occupy Wall Street.
They're not talking within the cluster.
They're talking separately.
And so, when they talk about taxes and they talk about inequality, it's not really resonating up here or at least the language is quite different.
And, it's a rule she tries to live by.
Richard Knox, NPR News.
It's NPR News.
Well, there's all sorts of signs of the characteristic breakdown of a presidency of orthodox innovation.
I don't think we're quite there yet.
In fact, I think this president has been quite remarkable.
Orthodox innovators, at least as I count them, very seldom are re-elected to second terms.

But we do see these kind of pent-up frustrations, the sign of failure to deliver on expectations, the failure to deliver the orthodoxy of the Social Security plan, the nomination of Harriet Miers, a disappointment.
So you do see these kind of tensions building.
I don't think we've seen actually leading figures.
We haven't seen the Bobby Kennedy of the Republican Party come out and break with the administration.
So I don't think we're quite there yet.

Today we don't really see, either in the Democratic Party or outside of the Democratic Party, the makings of a new movement that will exploit the weaknesses in this dominant coalition and take American politics into a new era and to a different era, not just the return of the old liberalism.
Thank you very much for joining us.
Thank you.

Stephen Skowronek is a professor of political and social science at Yale University and the author of the book ""The Politics Presidents Make."" His article on the Bush presidency will be published in the December issue of Perspectives on Politics.
This is NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Debbie Elliott.

But we begin our program with a visit to the home of Maryland National Guardsman Scott Fink.
We've been following his adjustment back to civilian life since he returned from a tour in Iraq.
I first met his wife, Monica(ph), in April of 2006, about a month before Scott came home.
I worry about what he's seen, if he will be able to adjust, if there's - if he does have like a stress disorder or how hard it will take him to go back to being - not normal.
I mean, everyone has their thing, but just go back to normal life - the normal things that we used to do and not have like flashbacks and things like that.
And then with the kids, just try to go back to how it used to be, just the same old routine -happy.
Monica took part in the Maryland National Guard's Family Readiness Program, a series of briefings that urged spouses not to expect too much when their soldier gets home.
A guard chaplain told them, you don't know what he's seen nor how he might have changed.
Just be thankful that he's home.
Dadadi, daddy.
Daddy.
Monica and the kids welcomed Scott home when his unit arrived at the local armory last summer.
I checked in with the family a few months later at their home in Olney, Maryland.
It hasn't settled yet.
But I know it never does.
It's just been an adjustment all around because he came home May.
I got pregnant in June and then I was sick for the first three months.
I just lay on couch.
It was a little hectic.
Coming from a war zone and, I mean, you're still a little bit on the edge and it's hard to get used to regular life again.
I found myself looking for roadside bombs on the side of the road.
Things are still a bit hectic in the Fink household.

Baby Abigail is wheezing a little.

But she's bright-eyed and fat-cheeked and Monica seems to be taking everything in stride.
For a little while, but I think he's getting better and better.
Now, like, me going back to work and getting a little bit of routine.

But I think we're getting used to it and stuff.

Thirty-six-year-old Scott has lost weight since the last time I saw him.
He fidgets, tapping his knees and twisting his hands as he talks.
Scott's National Guard unit is now back in Iraq, but he stayed behind to seek treatment for the post-traumatic stress disorder he didn't want to admit that he had.
It was very tough.
It was probably the hardest thing I ever did, is admitting that I needed help.

And I suppose that the Tea Party were in some way to affect the composition of Congress in this November's election, you would not necessarily be able to claim a mandate for your issues, would you?
Of the six players, Rahim herself is on the slate of Ayad Allawi, a secular Shiite who has attracted nationalists from both Shiite and Sunni-Arab communities.
Allawi was briefly prime minister, appointed by the Americans in 2004.
Two other politicians have tried to claim a non-sectarian nationalist label: Sitting Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki and the current interior minister, Jawad al-Bolani.
Both are Shiite, but have reached out to popular Sunnis.
The other major lists are a bit more homogenous.
Shiite religious parties have banded together with a deal reputed to have been made in Iran, including the anti-American cleric, Moqtada al-Sadr.
An almost purely Sunni-Arab coalition includes the speaker of parliament, Ayad al-Samarrai.
Samarrai is frank that he believes Iraqis will still vote more according to sect than any political program a candidate is offering.
The people will vote according to loyalty rather than to programs.
And when we reach to a point that people will vote for programs, than we can see there's no sectarian behavior affecting the election.
The last major factor is the Kurds, who actually have some bitter internal divisions.
But with regards to the parliament in Baghdad, Kurds are expected to maximize their poll and vote as a bloc.
Rowsch Shaways is a senior Kurdish politician and currently the deputy prime minister.
He says the Kurds feel confident that no coalition can form a government without them.
We are all awaiting the election, and then we will see what the negotiation then bring, depending on the results of the election.
Without big surprises, it will take at least three of the six major players to band together in order to form a government along with a few smaller independents.
Almost no combinations are out of the question.
Prime Minister Maliki is expected by many to get the most votes, but that doesn't guarantee he'll form the winning coalition.
Maliki himself became prime minister as a weak compromise candidate, and then slowly grew into a powerful figure.
Rend Rahim says that may happen again.
A prime minister emerging from a coalition of three or more political groups in parliament - these groups will want the prime minister to be weak.
They may feel that it is in their interest not to have another Maliki.
But she adds that Maliki may have shown that there's no such thing as a weak Iraqi prime minister.
